critique: This document pertains to the National Industrial Recovery Act and the textile industry in 1934. It concerns the timing of recommendations from various textile work assignment boards and their reporting requirements to the Secretary of Labor. Given the context of the Great Depression and the New Deal, the document reflects government intervention in the economy. There is no information related to immigration, executive power, federalism, national security, or social inclusion. The ideological tilt is moderately liberal due to the interventionist approach. The economic regulation is high, as it involves government boards overseeing industries. The other axes are neutral.
